node.text:
I wrote this short story for @learningforjustice magazine last year in the rise of anti-Asian hate crimes. This week I’m so excited to share the read aloud version with y’all which was recorded in my bathtub and illustrated by the incredibly talented @janiceechang! As May 18th was the National AAPI Day Against Bullying and Hate, it couldn’t have come at a better time. Please check out organizations like @acttochange that support this work year round.
.
I hope y’all can use it as a way to discuss stereotypes, bias, and what it means to avoid being a bystander and choosing to be an accomplice or co-conspirator. I’d love to hear how it goes with your students or children!

node.text:
“Why Palestine is a feminist issue.”
.
(A reminder that I can be proudly Jewish, believe in Jewish self determination, speak out against antisemitism, be critical of the Israeli government, and center my friend’s identity and work in this conversation. Also save your thumbs the effort before sending me angry messages that I’m not mirroring your every belief.)

node.title: Dr. Randa Tawil from the Palestinian Feminist Collective

node.text:
Alex and I are book twins!! Both of our books come out next week on 5/25. Alex’s is “Equity-Centered Trauma-Informed Education,” and mine is “Start Here, Start Now: A Guide to Antibias and Antiracist Work in Your School Community.”
.
Thank you Darla and Taylor for being our ASL interpreters!

node.text: Oh my gosh. Thank you Navjot of @saffronpress for sharing such incredible wisdom with us this evening, and educating us about the Sikh faith and the importance of acknowledging and valuing visible religious identities. Check out @saffronpress to see Navjot’s incredible picture books, and please take a few minutes to read up on the farmers protests in India. #istandwithfarmers

node.title: Sikhism and Representation with Navjot Kaur of Saffron Press

node.text: The ABAR meets religion and spirituality series continues!Thank you so much @alex.j.donovan for sharing your religious journey, and teaching us about your intersection of agnosticism and familial Celtic spirituality. It was wonderful to hear about how your faith influences your teaching folx who are new to Canada, and how you create space for your students to share their beliefs.

node.title: Alexander Donovan on Celtic Agnostic Spirituality

node.text:
OH MY GOSH. I have loved every conversation of this series and tonight’s talk with @mskass1 and @davidftelfort was mind blowing. I have never thought about abolition and liberation within the context of religion, and I so appreciate Kass for creating this partnership which has completely pushed my way of thinking.
.
Kass, thank you for sharing this part of your identity with us, and Reverend thank you for your vision of what can be possible in religious spaces.
.
In lieu of compensating today’s guests, please consider donating to Ms. E’s Go Fund Me. She’s an amazing teacher who holds DACA status and needs our support. http://gf.me/u/zb756m

node.title: Religion, Liberation, and Abolition with Kass Minor and Rev David Telfort

node.text: Thank you to the brilliant @asmahanmashrah for educating us about Islamic practices and beliefs, and how her way of life as a Muslim educator is intertwined with her social justice activism. Make sure you listen to the end to hear her suggestions about making schools inclusive for Muslim students!

node.title: Islam, Activism, and Education with Asmahan

node.text:
Maribel of @decolonizeliteracy shares her wisdom and experiences of Indigenous spirituality and how we can honor indigenous practices without appropriation.
.
Maribel is an incredible ABAR educator and consultant, so please check out her page if your school is in need of ABAR STEM support and guidance.

node.text:
The wonderful @dianedcosta (@dianemakesthings) shares her experiences growing up in Jewish culture as a person of color, and how we can work to make schools more religiously inclusive. 
.
As always, these interviews represent ONE person’s experience. Religious identities are not a monolith. 
.
CC video will be uploaded and shared via YouTube (@instagram please make it possible to CC IG Live videos to IGTV)

node.title: Judaism and Activism with Diane D’Costa

node.text:
Ace Schwarz (they/them) of @teachingoutsidethebinary talks about growing up Lutheran and the connection between faith and activism.
.
CC video: https://youtu.be/hj5imXMUnaU
.
Please consider donating to @pointofprideorg on Ace’s behalf!

node.title: Christianity and AntiBias & Antiracism with Ace Schwarz

node.text:
Thank y’all SO MUCH for joining in today’s event hosted by @auantiracismctr and moderated by the amazing @afrominimalist. If you registered but didn’t make the live event, the recording will be available (with ASL!) AND everyone can access the guidebook FOR FREE which is linked in my bio and Patreon. You can view my panel with @julyewilliams, the amazing keynote from @jasonreynolds83 , and learn more about anti racist teaching from Dr. Cheryl Holcomb-McCoy and Dr. Amanda Taylor!
.
I am so honored to be featured along with @britthawthorne @tiffanymjewell @corneliusminor and I hope the work we put in helps folx who are invested in anti racist work. Thank you @julyewilliams for your brilliance, and @cewigginton @autodidacticism of @pointmadelearning for distance-filming the digital series from all over the country during a pandemic. More thanks to @firstbookorg and @pizzahut for making this happen!

node.title: Empowering Educators: A Digital Series on Race and Racism

node.text:
A chat with @kshelton on “techquity,” anti racism in technology and education, and how educators can use tech in meaningful ways during distance schooling.
.
Venmo: @k_shelton
www.kennethshelton.net

node.title: Live with Ken Shelton on ABAR in technology and education

node.text:
I can’t believe it’s been two years since I made a physical anchor chart with kids!!! Over the past year in particular, most of the new folx on here know me as an educator/writer for adults, but my teacher identity will always be rooted in working with younger learners.
.
I don’t use language like community “norms,” because I feel like this often tends to marginalize some members. Community “agreements” must be co-constructed, otherwise they’re just top-down rules.
.
I’ve deeply appreciated working with my therapist around non-violent communication, which helps identify our feelings and needs, and I think translates beautifully to learning spaces. This week we’re talking about what learning spaces (classroom, library, wherever learning happens) should feel like, and what we can commit to in order to meet our needs and support each other.
.
Hella busy and stressful year with COVID still going on, but it’s wonderful to be around kids again.

May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'DICTIONARY.COM performative activism [per-fawr-muh-tiv ak-tuh-viz-uhm ] noun 1 Usher, Priyanka Chopra Jonas, and Julianne Hough will host competition series 'The Activist'. Activists go head-to-head in challenges to promote their causes, with their success measured via online engagement, social metrics, and hosts' input. (deadline.com/2021/09/ushe-...)'.

node.text:
Couldn’t help it 😬 But seriously, the hosts of a show about activism include a white woman who wore blackface, an actress who promotes colorism and talks down to actual activists, and… Usher?
.
This is gross on so many levels that a lot of folx have already pointed out. What I find additionally harmful is the focus on individuals vs. systemic change, and how it perpetuates scarcity mentality. Marginalized folx are already pitted against each other at the hands of white supremacy. There is nothing liberatory about this.

node.text:
Thank you @unconditionallearning for putting these very helpful slides together. If you’re new to my page, please read my “new folx” highlight.
.
Folx, I don’t have the capacity for free work. Not writing articles, not crafting questions for your book club, not speaking engagements. Please use the resources stored on this account, purchase my book if you’re able, ask your librarian to help you locate what you need. 
.
I appreciate y’all very much but please understand as a school based educator with a partner, family, friends, interests, and mental health that’s often hanging by a thread, I can only do so much.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Do Cite and credit authors appropriately We also love when you share our writing (books, articles, posts). Promoting our work can be tough; we are so grateful when you share. Remember to cite/tag appropriately. On Instagram and Twitter, tag us so folks can find our work. you're quoting or referencing a specific piece, include the title and year. Citation is political. Lift up others' work and how it influences yours.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Don't Confuse authors with our publishers Authors and scholars typically have little to no influence over pricing of books/articles, availability, or sales. Have questions about shipping, ordering, etc? Contact the publisher or your local bookstore, not the author directly. Can't get access to a paywalled article? Sometimes authors can help, but try a colleague or friend first if possible, and check ResearchGate and Google Scholar.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Do Your homework Before DMing us with a question, search for resources using Google and Google Scholar, look at our public work on blogs, and scroll back through posts (or use the search feature on Twitter). Check out our websites! The resource you're looking for is often easily available, and while it may not seem like a big deal to you to ask a quick question, lots of these can quickly add up.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Don't Ask for free work Authors and scholars work hard to create resources, writing, and more. Authors aren't paid for academic articles, and the price of a book mostly goes to publishers. you need individual or group consultation, coaching, written responses to questions, or feedback on your work, recognize that scholars and authors may have limited or no capacity to do these things for free. When reaching out with a request, be clear whether you are offering payment or requesting volunteered time and be gracious if you get a "no" in response.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 08, 2021. May be an image of flower and text that says 'Do Connect with authors and scholars to tell them you appreciate their work! Writers and scholars really appreciate your kind words, especially those about the impact of our work on your practice.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 08, 2021. May be an image of flower and text that says 'Do Build Budships relationships We all benefit from relationship-building and networking in our fields on social media. Leave comments, engage with posts and writing, do your own writing and share it! Mentorship can be a beautiful thing, and many authors and scholars are incredibly generous with their time when we are in a community with others. If you want to be connected, work on building those connections.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Blessing of Memory It is hard to sing of onenesss when our world is not complete, when those who once brought wholeness to our life have gone, and nothing but memory can fill the emptiness their passing leaves behind.'.

node.text:
I shared this prayer last year as we were alerted of the news of RBG’s passing in the middle of Erev Rosh Hashanah. I often feel lucky that as a Jew, I get to ring in the new year three months before the Gregorian new year. It’s a much needed reset and time of reflection.
.
This year, I share this prayer again as I look back over the past twelve months. We have and are still enduring unbearable loss. From the millions of people who have died from COVID (and we still have yet to collectively mourn), victims of climate change disasters, citizens who have lost their lives due to power hungry and oppressive governments, and so many more, this new year feels heavy.
.
Even though I do not know these millions of people and we might have never talked or laughed together or shared a meal, I still hold each of them in the light. May their memories be a blessing.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 06, 2021. Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'But memory can tell us only what we were, in company with those we loved; it cannot help us find what each of us, alone, must now become. Yet no one is really alone; those who live no more echo still within our thoughts and words, and what they did is part of what we have become.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on September 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We do best homage to our dead when we live our lives most fully, even in the shadow of our loss. For each of our lives is worth the life of the whole world; in each one is the breath of the Divine. In affirming God we affirm the worth of each one whose life, now ended, brought us closer to the source oflife, in whose unity no one is alone and every life finds purpose. -CHAIM STERN'.

node.text:
It’s back to school season, and I am already mid-fall exhausted. Here are a few reminders for those who are starting or continuing their ABAR journey.
.
We know this year is going to be intense so remember: You’re human. Give yourself grace.
.
Image description:
Slide 1: There is no “one size fits all” when it comes to antibias and antiracist work. 
Slide 2: Antibias and antiracist work is an ongoing process of learning and unlearning.
Slide 3: In antibias and antiracist work, there is no finish line to cross, or list of boxes to check.
Slide 4: Antibias and antiracist work is not a linear journey.
Slide 5: Antibias and antiracism work is a personal and communal commitment. It is not something that can be bought.
Slide 6: Antibias and antiracism is for everyone, because everyone holds biases and is capable of racial harm.

Left side of image: “If you’re talking about diversity, equity, inclusion, cultural responsiveness, antibias”
Right side of image: “Are you including race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, disability, body size, socioeconomic status, citizenship, age, religion language”

node.text:
I’m reposting this because @vasu_sojitra graciously called me in about how the graphic from yesterday is not inclusive for people with visual impairments. I’m incredibly grateful to always be learning and unlearning.
.
A lot of schools and organizations like to use the words on the left side when they’re really only focusing on race and racial justice. That’s important work, but not an reflection of what you’re actually doing. Additionally, some folx use words like “diversity” because saying “race” makes them uncomfortable. If you’re talking about race, racism, racial justice, or anti racism, it’s important to name it.
.
Many places that have focuses on DEI, antibias, or cultural responsiveness completely ignore all the social identities listed on the right hand side.
.
Don’t tell me you value diversity when you’re ignoring gender identities. 
.
Don’t tell me you value equity when you give non-Christians a hard time for  taking off religious holidays.
.
Don’t tell me you value inclusion when your language and activities are ableist or fatphobic.
.
Yes, educating yourself about all these identities is hard work and takes time, but it’s crucial to make social justice work as inclusive as possible.
.

Left side of image: “If you’re talking about diversity, equity, inclusion, cultural responsiveness, antibias”
Right side of image: “Are you including race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, disability, body size, socioeconomic status, citizenship, age, religion language”

May be an image of text that says 'Examples of ableist language I'm working to remove from my vocabulary: Crazy Insane Blindly Lame Tone deaf Crippled Colorblind to describe people who make this comment about not noticing race) Dumb ADD/OCD/bipolar (referring to a personality trait VS a diagnosis)'.

node.text:
Many of y’all have heard me refer to myself as an “ABAR educator in progress,” with emphasis on the “in progress.” Anti bias is an enormous umbrella and there are so many identities and experiences I do not hold.
.
In my book I mention that while editing, I came across a number of examples of ableist language that I caught and didn’t have the developed lens to notice when I began. A number of people have asked for examples, so here are a few to begin. Folx please feel free to share others in the comments (and mind the virtue signaling please.)
.
Edit: I’d also add the common allyship phrase “I stand with _____” which excludes those with certain physical disabilities.
.
Edit 2: Some people in my DMs need to take a breather. Notice that I’m not phrasing this post as “YOU ALL MUST DO THIS OR ELSE.” I just told y’all what I’m working on. To those who say I’m overreaching with words like “crazy” or “lame,” this is about the power of language and ensuring the dignity and humanity of people with disabilities. If you mean something is unexpected or boring, use those words. Additionally, “crazy” and “insane” are often used to gaslight women and BIPOC so I prefer not to use them. You do you.

node.text: It’s been two months and some change since my book was released. I can’t tell you how incredible it’s been to see these pages in so many hands and hear from folx how you’re interpreting, adapting, and implementing these practices. Thank y’all so so much for your support!!!
